lines.text:
[after examining the scene of stolen Pink Panther, Clouseau notices the wire on the floor]
Very ingenious.

[annoyed]
He pulled himself across the floor.
He did?
How else could he have avoided our radar field?
Yes, how else. Hmm. Of course he would have needed a very slippery floor to do that.
Therefore, the wax.
The wax? AGHH!
[Clouseau steps on the wax and falls to the floor]
Are you alright, Inspector?

[on his knees]
Of course I'm alright. I'm... examining the wax.
[sniffs the wax on the floor]
Have you taken a sample of this wax?
Wax is wax!
See, this is where you are wrong. Wax is NOT just wax. In this case it is a clue. Domestic wax, Belgian Wax, French Wax, English Wax...
Ah, the Inspector is right. Have the wax tested immediately.

[grabing the mechanical arm from the jewel stand]
It is my guess that you will find it is English wax.
Why?
Because your thief is an Englishman.
How do you know that?
It is my business to know that. He is Sir Charles Phantom, the notorious Lytton.
The Phantom?
Yes, one and the same.
[the mechanical arm grabs Clouseaus's crotch]
I am a musician and the monkey is a businessman. He doesn't tell me what to play, and I don't tell him what to do with his money.
[after an incident involving a blind beggar]
The beggar was the lookout man for the gang.
That is impossible.
Why?
He was blind. How can a blind man be a lookout?

[Insinuating Clouseau]
How can an idiot be a policeman? Answer me that!
It's very simple, all he has to do is enlist...
Shut up!
I arrest you, Sir Charles Phantom, the notorious pink Lytton.

[annoyed]
Are you blind?
Yes!
I see you are familiar with the falling-down-on-the-floor ploy.
[Cato has just attacked Clouseau, causing extensive damage to the restaurant he's eating in]
You fool! You raving Oriental idiot! There is a time and a place for everything, Cato! And this is it!
[Clouseau goes to attack Cato, but misses and destroys the restaurant's kitchen]
[Clouseau is having the hotel bellboy spy on Lady Lytton]
How long have you been a bellboy?
Oh, too long, Monsieur.
Keep up the good work, and I shall see to it you become a bell *man*.

[meaning the diamond]
All right, Darling, where is it?

[pretending to misunderstand]
After all these years, you still need to ask?
[to a Taxi driver]
Follow that car!
[driver gets out of the taxi and follows the car]

[after Clouseau's fiasco with the bank robbers]
... You are suspended for six months, without pay, effective immediately! Have you anything to say?
...Could you lend me fifty francs?

[after Clouseau has demolished two trucks and a swimming pool in Nice]
Now he's off to Gstaad. Today, a paradise in the Swiss Alps - tomorrow, a wasteland.
[rolls his eyes and lets out a deep breath]
Compared to Clouseau, Attila the Hun was a Red Cross volunteer!
Good Sharkey, Colonel God!
I will be forced to shoot you.
Who's forcing you?
[Chief Inspector Dreyfuss has gone berserk, shooting at Clouseau and Lytton]
He's out of ammunition.
He's out of his mind, that's what he's out of.

[in Dreyfus' office, after Clouseau's apartment has been bombed]
I tell you, infamous powers are at work! The instant you assign me to a case, the Underworld hears about it and I am set upon! It is amazing that I am still alive!

[forcing himself not to giggle]
"Amazing" is not the word.
Do I detect something in your voice that says I am in disfavor with you?
YES! I wish you were DEAD!
Well, of course, you are entitled to your opinion.

[at Lytton Manor in Nice, while working undercover as a telephone repairman, Clouseau has already annihilated the Lyttons' doorbell!]
... I am from the Nice Telephone Company; there is some trouble with your phone.
...I don't think there's any trouble with the telephones here.
I know when there is a trouble, and when there is not a trouble, and you may rest assured that there is a trouble.
Since when?
Since it was reported.
By whom? And what sort of trouble is it?
If I knew that, I could simply call you up and tell you what the trouble with your telephone is!
Well... Whatever the trouble is, I hope you locate it.
Madame, it is my business to locate trouble...
[He misses the door to the study, crashing headlong into the wall; being Clouseau, he isn't even fazed]
...Er, no trouble back there!

[Offscreen, Dreyfus accidentally fires a gun that he thought did not work. Francois rushes into Dreyfus's office to see what has happened]
Don't just stand there, idiot. Call a doctor. And then help me find my nose.

[answering the phone]
This is Monsieur Gadoire - who is this speaking?
Don't you know? HmmHmmm! Can't you guess? I'll give you a clue - this is the man who hates you. This is the man who more than anything else in the world would like to see you dead and buried!
...are you the headwaiter that works in the little bistro on the Rue de Bazaar?
This is very strange. I do not ever recall receiving the fortune cookie in a Japanese Restaurant.
What does yours say?
Beware of Japanese Waitress bearing fortune cookies
[to parrot]
Swine bird!
Cato is in hospital. They nearly blew his little yellow skin off!
[after inadvertently destroying much of the hotel he is in]
I must leave. Zis Hotel is deteriorating rapidly.
Does Lady Lytton have a swimming pewl?
A swimming pewl?
Describe your thoughts. Get them out in the open. You'll feel much better.

All right. See, it's always the same. Clouseau is sitting there, in a chair, just like you, with his back to me. Then suddenly, my hands go round his throat, and I begin to squeeze. It's wonderful. It's marvelous. I'm squeezing. And the more I squeeze, the freer I feel. I'm in ecstasy. And then suddenly, suddenly my problem is solv-ved.
[while Dreyfus has been talking, he has been unintentionally strangling the doctor. He suddenly becomes aware of this as the doctor falls to the floor]
Doctor! DOCTOR!
I did not know the bank was being robbed because I was engaged in my sworn duty as a police officer.

[referring to Clousseau]
How much do you hate him?
How high is up? I hate every little molecule in his body!
There's something about a wife, even with a beard.
You're breaking my fingers!
Well, why don't you call a policeman?
